lastfm.name: lastfm | fm
lastfm.description: \⚠ `[]` signifies the parameter is required, `<>` parameters and words ending with `?` are optional.

commands.name: fm set
commands.usage: `.fm set [lastfm username]` this links your Discord account to your Last.fm account, meaning when you use other commands such as fm or fmyt you won't need to define a username.

commands.name: fm remove | delete
commands.usage: `.fm remove` this unlinks your Discord account from your Last.fm.

commands.name: fm recent | recents
commands.usage: `.fm recent <track count> <lastfm user>` this displays a defined amount of recent tracks you have listened to recently, displayed differently depending on if you request 1, 2, or more than 2 tracks to be displayed.

commands.name: fm np
commands.usage: `.fm np <lastfm user>` this is shorthand for `.fm recent 1`

commands.name: fm
commands.usage: `.fm <lastfm user>` this is shorthand for `.fm recent 2`

commands.name: fmyt
commands.usage: `.fmyt` this searches YouTube for the song you're listening to/last listened to on Last.fm and returns it.

commands.name: fm topartists | ta
commands.usage: `.fm topartists <time period> <lastfm user>` this shows your most listened to artists for a given time period.

commands.name: fm topalbums | tal | tab
commands.usage: `.fm topalbums <time period> <lastfm user>` this shows your most listened to albums for a given time period.

commands.name: fm toptracks | tt
commands.usage: `.fm toptracks <time period> <lastfm user>` this shows your most listened to tracks for a given time period.

commands.name: fm profile
commands.usage: `.fm profile <lastfm user>` this displays some information about your last.fm profile.

commands.name: chart
commands.usage: `.chart artists? <time period> <grid size (e.g. 3x3)>` this displays a chart of your most listened to albums (or artists if "artists" is included) for the given time period.

youtube.name: youtube | yt
youtube.description: \⚠ `[]` signifies the parameter is required, `<>` parameters and words ending with `?` are optional.

commands.name: youtube | yt
commands.usage: `.youtube <query>` this searches YouTube for your query and returns the top result.

utility.name: utility
utility.description: \⚠ `[]` signifies the parameter is required, `<>` parameters and words ending with `?` are optional.

commands.name: translate | tr
commands.usage: `.translate <source language code>-?<target language code> <text>` this translates text either from a given source language or the auto-detected language of your text to your desired language and returns it (uses Bing translate :/)

commands.name: help
commands.usage: `.help <module name>` displays the commands under a given module and how to use them.

notification.name: notification | notif | noti
notification.description: \⚠ `[]` signifies the parameter is required, `<>` parameters and words ending with `?` are optional.

commands.name: notification add
commands.usage: `.notification global? add <type> [key word/phrase]` this adds a notification with they key word or phrase entered, meaning you will then be notified when a user mentions that word either in the server you add the notification to or in any server you and haseul bot are both in if you pass the global argument. You can also specify a type, determining whether it will be `strict`, `normal`, or `lenient` in deciding whether or not to match the key word/phrase.

commands.name: notification remove
commands.usage: `.notification remove [key word/phrase]` this removes a notification based on the key word or phrase you specify.

commands.name: notification list
commands.usage: `.notification list` this sends you a dm with a list of all your notifications, their type, and whether they are global or local notifications.
